<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<Tile> it = myTiles.iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}
<<<explanation>>>: The first example is creating a new Tile object inside the if statement, which means that the reference to the original Tile object is lost. In the second example, the Tile object is being assigned to the myTiles array directly, so the reference is preserved. This is why the second example works and the first example doesn't.
